entry.title: Solace Agent Mesh ü§ñüåê : Unlocking Scalable + Real-Time Agentic AI for SAP Customers
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community üëã

I would like to share some hands-on experience with the Solace Agent Mesh and how it could improve the way we build intelligent, event-driven applications in SAP landscapes. If you've been exploring agentic AI, SAP Joule, or event-driven architecture (EDA), this is a framework you need to know about!

I will share some more hands-on tutorials soon.
Feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to build with this.

 

üéØWhat is Solace Agent Mesh?
Solace Agent Mesh is an open-source, event-driven agentic AI framework that enables multiple specialized AI agents to work together seamlessly across your enterprise landscape. Think of it as the nervous system that connects all your intelligent agents, allowing them to communicate, collaborate, and execute complex workflows in real-time.‚Äã

I appreciate that it is open source. You can contribute and star ‚≠êÔ∏è their public repository here:
https://github.com/SolaceLabs/solace-agent-mesh

And learn more on their own website: 
https://solace.com/products/agent-mesh/

To start using the community edition, you can run this in your terminal:

mkdir my-sam && cd my-sam
python3 -m venv .venv && source .venv/bin/activate
pip3 install solace-agent-mesh
sam init --gui
sam run

then go to localhost:8000 to configure the agents and chat with the orchestrator!


Here's what makes it special for SAP customers:

‚úÖ Event-Driven Foundation ‚Äì Built on Solace+SAP Advanced Event Mesh, which SAP has partnered with for years to power SAP Event Mesh capabilities‚Äã

‚úÖ Enterprise-Grade Security ‚Äì Fine-grained access control, delegated permissions, and governance that meets SAP's security standards‚Äã

‚úÖ Real-Time Intelligence ‚Äì Agents react to live business events from SAP S/4HANA, Ariba, SuccessFactors, any third party and more‚Äã. This extends way beyond database updates; it can include camera video feeds üìπ, IOT üõú, phone calls üì≥, and much more.

‚úÖ Horizontal Scalability ‚Äì Asynchronous, decoupled architecture that scales with your business‚Äã. Agentic AI can truly scale in size and ambition; a network effect appears.

‚úÖ Multi-Agent Orchestration ‚Äì Intelligent orchestrator that breaks down complex tasks and delegates them to your specialized agents‚Äã: github agents do what they do best, salesforce does what they do best, and SAP Joule Agents excel all around your ERP!

 

üí°Why SAP Customers Should Care
As SAP professionals, we're living in an exciting time where agentic AI is transforming enterprise operations. SAP Joule is already showing us what's possible with AI agents in finance, procurement, supply chain, and HR. But here's the challenge: How do you connect these agents to real-time data across your entire IT landscape?‚Äã

This is where Solace Agent Mesh becomes invaluable:

üîó Seamless SAP Integration ‚Äì Direct integration with SAP S/4HANA via SAP Integration Suite, enabling real-time event consumption from your SAP systems‚Äã

‚ö° Event-Driven by Design ‚Äì Leverages SAP's event-driven architecture principles, working perfectly with SAP Event Mesh and SAP BTP‚Äã

ü§ñ Complements SAP Joule ‚Äì While Joule provides AI copilot capabilities within SAP applications, Solace Agent Mesh extends agentic intelligence across your entire multi-system landscape‚Äã

üåê Hybrid Cloud Ready ‚Äì Works across on-premise SAP ECC, S/4HANA Cloud, and third-party applications like Salesforce, Oracle, and custom systems‚Äã

 

üé¨Real-World Scenario: Intelligent Request for Quote (RFQ) Processing
Let me walk you through a powerful use case that showcases the magic of combining Solace Agent Mesh with SAP systems: Automated, Multi-System RFQ Processing.

The Business Challenge ü§î
Imagine you're a manufacturing company. A customer submits an RFQ by mail for 10,000 custom electronic components. To respond with an accurate, competitive quote, your team needs to:

Understand customer requirements (from Salesforce CRM)

Check product specifications (from SAP S/4HANA Product Catalog)

Verify current inventory (from SAP S/4HANA MM)

Assess production capacity (from real-time manufacturing systems/IoT)

Evaluate supplier pricing (from SAP Ariba)

Calculate optimal pricing (considering market conditions, customer history, margins)

Generate compliant quote (meeting regulatory and business rules)

Traditionally, this takes 3-5 days with multiple people manually gathering data from different systems, countless emails, and spreadsheet gymnastics üìäüòÖ. With Solace Agent Mesh, this can happen in seconds ‚ö°.

The Solution Architecture üèóÔ∏è
Here's how an event-driven multi-agent system would work:

1 - An incoming message of any nature becomes an event

2 - The Solace Orchestrator understands the situation and dispatches work to various other agents.

3 - Those agents are called through A2A, communication happens through events, topics, etc.

4 - The human sales team can oversee this process, and approve or modify the final quote.

5 - A high-quality, real-time answer can be quickly provided to the customer!

The Agent Team ü§ñü§ù
Let's meet the specialized agents working together:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Customer Intelligence Agent (Salesforce Integration)
Skills: Retrieves customer history, preferences, contract terms from Salesforce

Data: Past orders, payment history, negotiated discounts, relationship tier

Value: Ensures pricing aligns with customer agreements and maximizes conversion

2Ô∏è‚É£ Product Catalog Agent (SAP S/4HANA Integration)
Skills: Validates product codes, retrieves specifications, BOM data

Data: Technical specs, material master data, alternative products

Value: Ensures technical feasibility and suggests alternatives if needed‚Äã

3Ô∏è‚É£ Inventory Agent (SAP S/4HANA MM)
Skills: Real-time inventory checks, lead time calculations

Data: Current stock levels, reserved quantities, warehouse locations

Value: Provides accurate delivery timelines‚Äã

4Ô∏è‚É£ Production Capacity Agent (Manufacturing Systems/MES)
Skills: Analyzes real-time production schedules and machine availability

Data: Current production runs, machine uptime, capacity forecasts

Value: Validates if order can be fulfilled in requested timeframe‚Äã

5Ô∏è‚É£ Supplier Evaluation Agent (SAP Ariba)
Skills: Assesses supplier pricing, quality ratings, delivery performance

Data: Supplier catalogs, negotiated rates, risk scores

Value: Optimizes make-vs-buy decisions and supplier selection‚Äã

6Ô∏è‚É£ Pricing Optimization Agent (Multi-Source)
Skills: Calculates optimal pricing considering costs, margins, competition

Data: Raw material costs, labor rates, overhead, market pricing, customer willingness-to-pay

Value: Maximizes profitability while remaining competitive‚Äã

7Ô∏è‚É£ Quote Generation Agent (Orchestrator)
Skills: Aggregates all inputs, applies business rules, generates formatted quote

Data: Compiled data from all agents, compliance requirements, approval thresholds

Value: Produces compliant, accurate quote ready for customer delivery‚Äã


Why This Architecture Wins üèÜ
üöÄSpeed: What took 3-5 days now takes minutes

‚úÖAccuracy: Real-time data from source systems eliminates manual errors and outdated information‚Äã

üí∞Cost Efficiency: Agents manage data intelligently; only relevant information sent to LLMs, reducing token costs‚Äã

üîíSecurity: Fine-grained access control ensures agents only access data they're authorized for‚Äã

üìàScalability: Handle thousands of RFQs simultaneously without adding headcount‚Äã

üîÑAdaptability: Add new agents (e.g., sustainability scoring, compliance checking) without disrupting existing workflows‚Äã

üåêMulti-System: Seamlessly orchestrates SAP, Salesforce, manufacturing systems, and external data sources‚Äã

 

üîßTechnical Integration with SAP
For the SAP technical integration, here's how you'd integrate this:

SAP S/4HANA Integration

# Example SAC configuration for SAP S/4HANA agent agent: name: "ProductCatalogAgent" type: "adk" connections: - name: "S4HANA_Connection" type: "odata" url: "${S4HANA_ODATA_URL}" auth: type: "oauth2" token_url: "${S4HANA_TOKEN_URL}" tools: - name: "GetProductDetails" description: "Retrieve product specifications from SAP S/4HANA" api_endpoint: "/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PRODUCT_SRV"


SAP Event Mesh Integration

# Event Mesh configuration for event-driven triggers event_broker: type: "solace" connection: host: "${SAP_EVENT_MESH_HOST}" vpn: "${SAP_EVENT_MESH_VPN}" auth: type: "oauth" subscriptions: - topic: "sap/s4hana/product/changed" - topic: "sap/ariba/supplier/updated" - topic: "salesforce/opportunity/created"

SAP Integration Suite Connection
You can use the Solace Micro-Integration for SAP Integration Suite to connect your agents to SAP Event Mesh. This allows:‚Äã
- Consuming events from SAP S/4HANA business events‚Äã
- Publishing agent results back to SAP systems‚Äã
- Supporting both guaranteed (persistent) and direct messaging‚Äã

 

üéØBenefits Beyond RFQ Processing
The Solace Agent Mesh architecture isn't limited to RFQs. SAP customers can apply this pattern to:

üì¶ Supply Chain Orchestration ‚Äì Agents monitor inventory levels, predict stockouts, automatically trigger purchase requisitions in SAP Ariba‚Äã

üí∞ Accounts Payable Automation ‚Äì Invoice matching agents reconcile POs, goods receipts, and invoices across SAP FI, SAP MM, and supplier portals‚Äã

üè≠ Predictive Maintenance ‚Äì IoT agents detect equipment anomalies, automatically create maintenance orders in SAP S/4HANA, schedule technicians from SuccessFactors‚Äã

üë• Employee Onboarding ‚Äì HR agents coordinate document collection, account creation, training schedules across SuccessFactors, Active Directory, and learning systems‚Äã

üõí Order-to-Cash Optimization ‚Äì Sales agents validate orders against contracts, check credit limits, optimize delivery schedules across SAP SD, SAP FI, and logistics systems‚Äã

 

üöÄGetting Started
Ready to explore Solace Agent Mesh for your SAP landscape? Here's how to begin:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Start Small ‚Äì Pick one high-volume, repetitive process (like RFQ or invoice matching) that involves SAP and non-SAP. systems

2Ô∏è‚É£ Identify Your Agents ‚Äì Map out which systems need to be queried and what data is needed

3Ô∏è‚É£ Set Up Event Mesh ‚Äì Configure SAP Event Mesh or Solace PubSub+ to connect your systems‚Äã

4Ô∏è‚É£ Build Your First Agent ‚Äì Use the Solace Agent Mesh framework to create a simple agent that queries SAP S/4HANA‚Äã

5Ô∏è‚É£ Add Orchestration ‚Äì Deploy the orchestrator to coordinate multiple agents‚Äã

6Ô∏è‚É£ Scale Gradually ‚Äì Add more agents and complexity as you gain confidence

 

Resources üìö
Solace Agent Mesh GitHub: github.com/SolaceLabs/solace-agent-mesh‚Äã

SAP Integration Suite Documentation: Connect SAP systems to Solace Event Mesh‚Äã

Solace Codelabs: Getting started tutorials‚Äã

SAP BTP Event-Driven Architecture Reference: Best practices for EDA on SAP BTP‚Äã

 

üé¨Conclusion
The future of SAP is event-driven and agentic ü§ñ‚ö°.


By combining SAP's powerful business applications with Solace Agent Mesh's intelligent orchestration, we can build systems that:

- React in real-time to business events

- Make intelligent decisions across multiple systems

- Scale effortlessly as your business grows

- Maintain enterprise-grade security and governance

Whether you're working with SAP S/4HANA, SAP Ariba, SAP SuccessFactors, or integrating with Salesforce, Oracle, and custom systems, Solace Agent Mesh provides the event-driven backbone to make your agentic AI vision a reality.

I'd love to hear your thoughts! Have you experimented with event-driven architectures or agentic AI in your SAP landscape? What use cases are you most excited about?

Happy coding, and may your events always flow smoothly! üöÄ‚ú®

entry.title: What‚Äôs new with SAP Business AI, Joule, and Joule Agents in the SAP SuccessFactors 2H 2025 release
entry.content:
SAP SuccessFactors‚Äô second half 2025 release represents a major leap forward for AI capabilities across our HCM solutions, beginning with the introduction of our first of many planned AI agents. These agents, led by SAP‚Äôs copilot, Joule, mark a pivotal shift in how HR leaders will use artificial intelligence to create more responsive, efficient, and human-centered workplaces. Let‚Äôs look at our new AI agent and some other key AI-related highlights in the 2H 2025 release.

Empowering Managers with the Performance and Goals Agent

The newly available Performance and Goals Agent helps managers lead more meaningful performance conversations. By automatically gathering relevant data, from goals and achievements to feedback, Joule delivers personalized discussion points and suggests follow-up actions like scheduling one-on-one meetings or updating goals. This elevates coaching from administrative to strategic, enabling truly continuous performance management. If you want to learn more about the AI agents for HCM announced recently at SAP Connect, please visit this page.

 Joule Integration with Microsoft 365 Copilot

Through its integration with Microsoft 365 Copilot, Joule now connects data and workflows from Teams, Outlook, OneDrive, and SharePoint directly within SAP SuccessFactors. This unified experience reduces the need to switch between systems, letting users complete tasks, retrieve insights, and make decisions directly in the flow of work.

Smarter Pay Transparency with Explain Pay

Employee Central Payroll users in Germany, Mexico, and Brazil can now access the Explain Pay feature in Joule. The capability provides natural-language explanations for pay-related questions, cutting resolution time by up to 50%. This delivers the transparency and trust employees increasingly expect while decreasing HR support load.

Expanding Generative AI Access and Joule Actions

SAP has expanded generative AI availability to private-sector customers in Saudi Arabia, offering AI-assisted writing and goal-setting across HR workflows. The update also broadens Joule Actions, allowing users to upload files, view employer information, access extended time-off data, and create half-day leave requests, all via conversational prompts.

Learn More

In short, the 2H 2025 release of SAP SuccessFactors strengthens the platform‚Äôs role as an intelligent, interconnected HR ecosystem that drives productivity, trust, and engagement, all powered by Joule and SAP Business AI. You can discover more 2H 2025 innovations across the suite by checking out the release highlights brochure, overview video featuring Bianka Woelke, and much more on the Product Release & Road Map Information page.

Together, these innovations demonstrate SAP‚Äôs vision for an HR future where AI doesn‚Äôt just support processes, it redefines them. By embedding agentic intelligence throughout SuccessFactors, SAP gives HR leaders the tools to transform data into action, decisions into impact, and every moment at work into a more connected, individualized experience.

entry.title: Building Trust in AI: SAP Business AI earns ISO/IEC 42001 Certification
entry.content:
Artificial intelligence is reshaping how businesses operate, innovate, and serve their customers. But as AI becomes more deeply embedded into enterprise systems, ensuring that it behaves responsibly is just as important as making it powerful. 

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre proud to share that‚ÄØSAP Business AI has achieved ISO/IEC 42001:2023 certification‚ÄØ‚Äî the‚ÄØworld‚Äôs first international standard for Artificial Intelligence Management Systems (AIMS). 
This certification covers‚ÄØJoule,‚ÄØSAP AI Core, and‚ÄØSAP AI Launchpad, reinforcing SAP‚Äôs long-standing commitment to building trustworthy, transparent, and ethical AI‚ÄØacross our products and services. 

Why This Matters 

Responsible AI isn‚Äôt just a principle. It‚Äôs a prerequisite for scaling AI safely in enterprise environments. The ISO/IEC 42001 standard provides a structured framework that guides how organizations manage AI across strategy, governance, data, compliance, and sustainability. 

For SAP, this certification validates that our approach to AI meets globally recognized standards for‚ÄØfairness, accountability, reliability, and security. It means our customers and partners can rely on SAP AI solutions that are developed, deployed, and maintained with integrity. 

What the Certification Covers 

The certification recognizes SAP‚Äôs efforts to embed responsible AI practices throughout the entire AI lifecycle: 

  • Establishing a comprehensive‚ÄØAI Management System (AIMS)‚ÄØaligned with ISO 42001. 
  • Integrating‚ÄØAI security, ethics, and compliance controls‚ÄØat every stage of AI development. 
  • Enabling‚ÄØcross-functional collaboration‚ÄØamong engineering, legal, governance, and compliance teams. 
  • Successfully passing an‚ÄØindependent third-party audit‚ÄØthat assessed SAP‚Äôs operational excellence in AI governance. 

The certification scope includes‚ÄØJoule,‚ÄØSAP AI Core, and‚ÄØSAP AI Launchpad, along with SAP‚Äôs internal IT processes and AI governance policies. 

Responsible AI in Practice 

The ISO 42001 certification underscores that SAP Business AI is built on the foundation of responsible AI. 
In practice, this means: 

  • Fairness and Transparency:‚ÄØAI results are explainable, unbiased, and clearly communicated to end users. 
  • Reliability and Security:‚ÄØAI models are developed and deployed with robust safeguards around data use, access, and protection. 
  • Ethical Alignment:‚ÄØEvery AI solution undergoes an ethics evaluation to ensure consistency with SAP‚Äôs sustainability and compliance goals. 
  • Continuous Adaptability:‚ÄØGovernance and risk management evolve as new technologies and regulations emerge. 

Benefits for Our Ecosystem 

For‚ÄØcustomers and partners, this milestone brings clear advantages: 

  • Confidence that SAP AI systems are developed and managed under a certified, globally recognized framework. 
  • Reduced compliance burden through alignment with international and regional AI regulations. 
  • Stronger data integrity and security safeguards that protect sensitive business information. 
  • The ability to demonstrate responsible AI usage within their own operations and industries. 

Even for SAP teams, the ISO 42001 certification is more than a badge of compliance. It has been a powerful catalyst for collaboration. It‚Äôs brought together experts in technology, policy, and compliance to strengthen how we design, test, and deliver AI. This shared framework helps us innovate faster and smarter, with accountability built into every step. 

A Step Toward the Future 

The ISO/IEC 42001:2023 certification is a key milestone in SAP‚Äôs ongoing commitment to‚ÄØresponsible AI and customer success. It strengthens the foundation we‚Äôve built to ensure every advancement in‚ÄØSAP Business AI delivers innovation with integrity. 

As AI evolves, so will SAP‚Äôs dedication to keeping it‚ÄØreliable, transparent, and aligned with our customers‚Äô trust and business goals. 

Learn more about SAP Business AI‚ÄØand how we‚Äôre shaping the future of responsible enterprise AI.

entry.title: SAP User Experience Update: What‚Äôs New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA 2025 comes with a whole host of user experience innovations and improvements.  Web access via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad has many useful improvements, as does SAP Mobile Start for mobile access. Joule gives conversational access to Private Cloud Edition using natural language, now also with analytical insights. There are additional collaboration capabilities, and many improvements in details: some towards providing a more consistent and integrated SAP Business Suite, some simply making a user‚Äôs life easier. Finally, design and UI technology is also advancing, with powerful AI support for developers now available.

This post covers:

  • UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite
  • Web access: My Home and SAP Fiori launchpad
  • Mobile access: SAP Mobile Start
  • Joule
  • Situation Handling news
  • AI-Assisted capabilities: outlook
  • New collaboration capabilities
  • UX improvements in details
  • UI adaptation improvements for key users
  • Design and Technology news

If you want to get an impression of how good SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, looks across all the main product areas, have a look at the online Product Tour.

Since this post covers what‚Äôs new, building on the previous 2023 release, you might want to have a look at the UX innovations which came with the Feature Pack Stacks 00, 01 and 02 of the 2023 release:

  • SAP User Experience Update: What‚Äôs New for SAP S/4HANA 2023 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • User Experience Advances with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • SAP User Experience Q4/2024 News for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023.

For a full overview of what‚Äôs new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the documentation (note that it includes features from the above 2023 FPS01 and FPS02 blog posts, as well as this one):

  • What‚Äôs New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite

We aim to provide a consistent and integrated experience for all users of the SAP Business Suite, which means providing an entry point for users to access all the various SAP products within the suite, and ensuring that the user experience across these products is consistent, making it easy for users to use applications from different products.

Entry Points

Figure 1 shows our approach for providing a web and a native mobile entry point to the products of the suite, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud. I‚Äôd like to highlight that Joule can also be seen as an entry point to access the entire suite, since our goal is to provide Joule wherever you are, be it in our web applications or native mobile apps. Using Joule, our goal is to allow users to query and perform actions on all the products and applications which they are authorized to use, simply using natural language. As you‚Äôll see below, we are making good progress towards this goal.

Figure 1: Entry points providing an integrated workplace for accessing the SAP Business Suite. Alt Text: Image showing Joule on the left, ‚Äúavailable web and mobile‚Äù, and on the right a diagram with boxes indicating that SAP Mobile Start, SAP Start, and SAP Build Work Zone provide central access to SAP, with three boxes below for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors and Other SAP Products.

Web Central Access

I have covered recent UX innovations in our web central entry points, such as SAP Start and SAP Build Work Zone, and central services such as SAP Task Center, in my recent cloud UX blog posts. Since these capabilities also apply to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well as SAP S/4HANA (except for SAP Start), I will not repeat them here, but rather refer you to them:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 What we will look at in this post in detail are UX innovations for local access from web or mobile, via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad, and via SAP Mobile Start. Each has a dedicated section further below.

Design Updates for Suite Consistency

To achieve consistency across the suite, we have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we‚Äôll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence, we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 2. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry ‚ÄúAll Spaces‚Äù at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the ‚ÄúFavourite App‚Äù eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder ‚ÄúInsights‚Äù for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar ‚Äì need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case ‚ÄúS/4HANA Cloud‚Äù as you can see at the top of Figure 2. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (e.g. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments ‚Äì in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature ‚Äú/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE‚Äù.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 3 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the ‚ÄúSign Out‚Äù option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

 Figure 3: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a ‚Äúmore‚Äù link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 3 fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, and provides simpler interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by ‚ÄúToday‚Äù, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Week‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 4 shows two examples ‚Äì one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

 Figure 4: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing ‚Äúsearch‚Äù. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

 

Web Access: My Home and SAP Fiori Launchpad

The 2025 release brings a number of improvements in My Home, the start page in the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as some improvements in the launchpad itself (beyond the design updates mentioned above) ‚Äì for users as well as for administrators.

My Home

Here is an overview of the enhancements with this release:

  • To-Dos:
    • Tasks: Enhanced workflow relevant information and in-place actions
    • Situations from both standard and extended framework- are displayed
  • Intelligent homepage experience to boost productivity (cloud only):
    • Intelligent app recommendations.
    • Intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards.
  • Improved user experience: 
    • Drag & drop is now enabled in the insights section, so you can directly rearrange your tiles and cards.
    • Information about deprecated apps: any such apps are marked with an ‚Äúdeprecated2 icon .
  • Manage News application.

 This collection of videos shows the individual features of My Home ‚Äì both new and already existing ones:

  • My Home - Deep Dive (video collection)

Figure 5: My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA2025. Alt Text: A screenshot showing all the sections of My Home: To-Dos with tabs for Tasks (selected) and Situations;, a row with News on the left and Pages showing 8 pages on the right; Apps, with tabs for Favorites (selected ‚Äì showing 2 folders and 7 apps), Most Used, Recently Used, Recommended; Insight Tiles, showing 8 tiles; Insights Cards, showing 4 cards, 1 with a list and 3 with charts.

To-Dos Enhancements

The To-Dos task cards now offer action buttons, for example to approve or reject items. Often, this requires some key information about the item, for example the name of the product and the value for a purchase requisition. These details are now visualized directly in the task cards, as you can see in Figure 5, making the workflow more efficient.

Already with the 2023 release we made it possible for partners and customers to create their own situation objects with ABAP Development Tooling (ADT) via developer extensibility. Data Context supported by the Extended Framework

The data context is business data from business objects involved in a situation instance that can be collected, distributed, and used for advanced analytics ‚Äì for example using the Monitor Situations ‚Äì Extended app. If enabled in a situation type, data context is collected when a situation instance is created, updated, or completed. For example, If you use the situation template Quantity Deficit in Supplier's Delivery to inform specific members in your purchasing organization about a deficit in the quantity of materials to be delivered by the supplier, you'll get, for example, the material, plant, or supplier as part of the data context.

With the 2025 release, every extended object-based situation template supports data context. You can activate it in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app. Doing so results in an event being triggered that includes the data context every time a situation instance is created, updated or completed. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúGeneric Keyboard Interactions‚Äù.

Figure 24: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúJournal Entries (43,854)‚Äù. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using ‚ÄúCmd + D‚Äù to delete.

Automatic Update of SAP Fiori Apps Upon Change of Data in Backend

There are quite a few cases where users would appreciate seeing absolutely up-to-date data in their application, so that the data is automatically updated if changes occur in the backend. These changes could be made by other users, or by automated background processing . An example for the latter is the Traceability Results application, which is now automatically updated if a batch run has created new traceability items.

Note that this only supported by applications built with SAP Fiori elements using OData V4.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time ‚Äì magic!

Figure 25: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 25. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 26 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 26: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù with two new fields ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù, being edited with the value 3000, and ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù, containing the value 300.

Table Grouping and/or ‚ÄúShow more per row‚Äù State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if ‚Äúshow more per row‚Äù was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 27, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is ‚ÄúBestRun US‚Äù. In the popover ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 27: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over ‚ÄúColumn Settings‚Äù with two sections ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù and ‚ÄúGroup By‚Äù. The ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section has two lines, ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù and ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing ‚Äúno sorting‚Äù, ‚Äúascending‚Äù, ‚Äúdescending‚Äù.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 28), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 28: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúView Settings‚Äù containing tabs ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù, ‚ÄúSort‚Äù, ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù, and a pop-over ‚ÄúFilters‚Äù with two options ‚ÄúHide descriptions‚Äù (selected) and ‚ÄúHide Unselected‚Äù (deselected) . ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù, followed by ‚ÄúCreated On‚Äù ‚Äì i.e. the description column ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù is not listed next to the ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list of what‚Äôs new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the What‚Äôs New Viewer:

  • What‚Äôs New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UI adaptation improvements for key users

We have made significant enhancements to UI Adaptation for key users with the 2025 release. The ‚ÄúAdapt UI‚Äù option which key users see in their user menu shows you what you can change in the app, in a very intuitive way. And you can change and adapt far more than in the past. See below for some highlights.

Also good to know: the Adapt UI menu entry is also available when using a Classic app (SAP GUI for HTML) from within the SAP Fiori launchpad. It will bring up the Adapt UI app for Screen Personas F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas, which allows key users to adapt the layout of these classic UIs.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù as shown in Figure 27. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example ‚ÄúUS Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)‚Äù as shown in Figure 2.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Far More Options for Key Users to Adapt UIs

Key users can now make far more significant changes to UIs than before. For example, they can add a button to clear all filter values in the filter bar, remove buttons such as the ‚ÄúExport to Excel‚Äù, and much more. Figure 29 shows the options for configuring a table for example.

Figure 29: Many more options for Key Users to adapt UIs. Alt Text: UI Adaptation is shown switched on for the application Manage Bank Hierarchies, with a popover called ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù filling half the screen, and showing 12 options such as ‚ÄúEnable Table Export‚Äù, ‚ÄúFrozen Column Count‚Äù with a field for entering the number, ‚ÄúSorting‚Äù, ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù etc.

 

Design and Technology News

For a comprehensive overview of the recent design and technology news, have a look at my blog posts from Q1 and Q3 2025. These are also relevant for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 release, since the design and technology are already available in the cloud:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
    Note though that the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard presented there is currently only integrated with for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We are progressing at such a pace, that I have some additional news to share with you, not covered by the above posts. In addition, I would like to explicitly mention some particular highlights here from the above posts too.

Regarding extensibility: do have a look at the new SAP Extensibility Explorer.

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits ‚Äì now with AI Components

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

We have just released SAP Web UI Kit v8.0 which includes a full set of AI components: AI Button, AI Menu Button, AI Split Menu Button, AI Prompt Input, AI Input, AI Text Area, and AI Rich Text Editor.

Figure 30: The SAP Design System portal start page (on the left), and SAP‚Äôs UI Kits for designers in Figma (on the right). Alt Text: Two screenshots. The portal page shows four main sections SAP Fiori for Web, ‚Ä¶ for Android, ‚Ä¶ for iOS, and SAP Digital Design System, each followed by links to UI elements, Figma kits, and overviews. The UI Kits show 8 cards, SAP Fiori for Android, Web, iOS, watchOS, Wear OS, Performance, Accessibility and SAP S/4HANA.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

SAP Fiori Development Portal

I‚Äôm also happy to inform you about the new SAP Fiori development portal, introduced a few weeks ago. It is designed to help developers maximize the benefits of SAP Fiori elements for OData V4, which is more than just a UI framework: it‚Äôs a metadata-driven approach that leverages the SAP Design System as its guiding principle, incorporating the most relevant design system options for typical business tasks.

Figure 31: The SAP Fiori development portal. Alt text: A screenshot showing the Introduction page. On the left a menu has entries Using the Portal, Building Blocks, Global Patterns, Floorplans, SAP Fiori Tools. The Introduction page has a full width card ‚ÄúBuilding Blocks‚Äù at the top, with a description and tiles representing various building blocks. Below that ‚ÄúChoose Your Option‚Äù heading above two side-by-side cards for ‚ÄúFloorplans‚Äù and ‚ÄúCustomer Layout‚Äù, each with an image and description, and a ‚ÄúLearn More‚Äù button.

The SAP Fiori development portal puts building blocks front and center. These building blocks - such as tables, forms, filter bars, and charts - are orchestrated by SAP Fiori elements and form the basis of every OData V4 application. They provide standardized layouts and interaction patterns, ensuring UI consistency and boosting developer productivity. The great advantage of using building blocks is that you can use them to create a customer layout and yet still benefit from the advantages of the metadata driven approach: low code, built in enterprise-grade capabilities such as multi-language support, accessibility, security and performance, and design system consistency.

Find out more in this six-part series of blog posts, here is the first one, which contains links to the others:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6).

Using AI to Develop UIs

The above posts from Q1/2025 and Q3/2025 introduced a number of powerful ways to accelerate UI development by using AI, such as:

  • Creating SAP Fiori elements apps from a sketch (in the Q1 post), now integrated in SAP Build Code and Joule (Q3 post)
  • Joule for SAPUI5 freestyle development (Q1 post)
  • AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter (Q3 post)

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers provide AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information, and thus provide developers with valuable support. Figure 32 shows examples. 

Figure 32: Examples of the UI5 MCP Server (on the left) and the MCP Server for SAP Fiori (on the right) in action. Alt Text: both images show screenshots of a CLINE console view with a task entered as text at the top, followed by a list of steps which the system proposes to do to solve the task.

 Read about these new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don‚Äôt accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging ‚Äì so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2 

Blue Crystal and Belize Themes No Longer Available in the Web

As announced in April (Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal), the visual themes Blue Crystal and Belize have been removed from our web UI technology with the 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

 After upgrading, existing usages of Belize or Blue Crystal will be automatically redirected to the Horizon theme.

If you have created your own custom theme based on Belize or Blue Crystal using the UI theme designer, you will need to migrate this to an available theme. Our strong recommendation is to base the new version on the Horizon theme.

For more information about the web UI technologies affected, and how to migrate custom themes, have a look at this blog post:

  • Announcement: Removal of Belize theme of SAP Fiori.

Note that SAP GUI for Windows continues to support older themes, including Blue Crystal and Belize.

 

Final words

Come join us at TechEd 2025, November 4 - 6, either virtually or in Berlin, or at one of the TechEd On The Road events in Louisville (USA), Bangalore (India) and Sydney (Australia), to find out more about our latest user experience innovations. I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, so feel free to approach me after my talks if you have any specific questions. I‚Äôm looking forward to meeting some of you!

 This blog posts gives an overview of all the UX related sessions at all four events:

  • Exciting UX talks at TechEd ‚Äì Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia).

 Please continue using the community to share your learnings and best practices, either by posting articles yourselves or via comments on this post. You can also follow me in the community if you want to be notified about further similar updates from me.

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading üòä Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But let‚Äôs be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate company‚Äôs workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is close to being the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, but a technology that is to being considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI ‚Äì to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isn‚Äôt it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism üòä Guessing the comments like, ‚Äúthat is not for productive environment‚Äù, ‚ÄúDGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businesses‚Äù and many other sharp negatives. But let‚Äôs move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why I‚Äôve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. In such deployment it will be able to process 1 440 emails and create postings in SAP a day, that gives us 43 200 a month and amazing number of 518 400 documents a year!! All powered by one DGX Spark GPU-unit keeping the data on premise and avoiding cloud consumption.

That is what we call a proper deployment of Business AI. And Small and Medium businesses do not usually have such big number of documents from vendors, even the Cirque du Soleil does not have according to the latest SAP news post üòä What we usually do, we add extra Business AI scenarios to be processed by the same Skybuffer AI deployment.

Example #2: Automation of SAP user management services

Small and Medium businesses do use password-based login to SAP backend, so users keep locking themselves or forgetting their passwords. Do we need a powerful GPU-unit with the full size LLM to automate this? No, for sure. We can add those business scenarios to the AI Agent that is processing Vendor Emails üòä

Example #3: Bank data reconciliation

The same setup can be used to assist financial department to match bank transactions to the billing documents in SAP and post accruals for the cases that could not be reconciled, for example, those that miss billing data in SAP that is not created just because someone has forgotten to enter it or integration interfaces have data processing issues. DGX Spark GPU-unit provides particularly good enough capacity here as well.

Those are just a few examples that wind away the skepticism about the utilization of DGX Spark in productive environment.

Is it safe to invest in the on-premise Business AI setup?

If you need full control over costs and data security, the answer is yes. And we think that the answer is yes in general, because Skybuffer AI dual deployment capabilities gives companies the guarantee that on premise Business AI investment can follow their potential future cloud strategy. I am writing and hearing again ‚Äúwhat is this crazy man talking about! On premise investment can follow cloud strategies?? That is a paradox!‚Äù. And again, the answer is No, of course there is no paradox! If we look at the deployment of Skybuffer AI with integration with SAP Joule:

 Figure 02: Skybuffer AI deployment in SAP BTP with integration with SAP Joule

That is what we call real flexibility!

Sounds like a Gap Closing Solution?

Yes, that is the conclusion we have. There no hard choice anymore to run Business AI on premise or on SAP BTP, no prerequisites to start using Business AI, because the deployment in this article works with SAP ECC (down to 7.01 and even below), SAP S/4HANA on premise or SAP S/4HANA in private cloud. The only question must be asked, when we are talking about Business AI, is about the scenario the company should start with? You‚Äôve seen in our examples that Business AI deployments might bring benefits working in the scenarios that are independent from the historical data you have in your SAP backend and the historical data quality (sometimes it is called data silos), or scenarios that are independent from the version of your system and the point in time of your current digital journey. entry.title: How Redwood Software and SAP are shaping the next era of automation with Joule Studio

Introduction

Over the past year, Redwood Software has taken major steps forward in our long-standing partnership with SAP, turning the vision of conversational, agentic automation into something you can see and use today.

As Field CTO at Redwood, I‚Äôve spent many years helping SAP customers orchestrate their most critical workloads. Our shared mission with SAP has always been clear: make complex processes simpler, more reliable and, ultimately, autonomous.

Embedding automation into conversation with Joule Studio

In my previous post, I introduced how RunMyJobs by Redwood connects with SAP Joule Studio to transform automation into natural conversation. Since then, we‚Äôve built a tech preview that demonstrates a use case for how RunMyJobs‚Äô interoperability with SAP Joule makes agentic orchestration a reality you can scale for your most mission-critical processes.

One example is an autonomous, unplanned SAP system maintenance workflow. Traditionally, this requires multiple manual steps and cross-team coordination to pause background jobs, stop dependent integrations and verify dependencies. The SAP BTP team often has to schedule, stop or undeploy iFlows ad hoc, while the Basis team handles job suspension separately. Thus, it‚Äôs a fragmented process filled with stress and risk.

Today, an SAP Basis administrator can take a more goal-oriented approach. They can simply tell Joule what they need to do: 

‚ÄúSafely execute the SAP system maintenance procedure, including a pause on all dependent workflows associated with the system to avoid job failures.‚Äù

Joule triggers the complete, pre-approved workflow across RunMyJobs and the relevant SAP systems. Acting as an interactive control tower for the entire event, it executes pre-approved RunMyJobs workflows, coordinates with integrations and provides real-time progress and approval updates through natural language with either business or IT users.

For example, Joule might respond: 

‚ÄúAll background jobs are paused, and Integration Suite iFlows are offline. Do you approve the system restart now, or do you want to send an approval request to the system administrator for a restart?‚Äù 

Once the administrator confirms, the automated workflow proceeds to the next step.

üëâSee Joule in action with RunMyJobs here:

 

What we learned building Joule skills

Working with Joule Studio‚Äôs low-code design canvas confirmed how quickly governed automation can be delivered through conversational interfaces. Our approach focused on four essentials:

  1. Natural conversation design: Translating how SAP users actually phrase requests into machine-understandable prompts
  2. Action orchestration: Linking RunMyJobs APIs or pre-built SAP Accelerator Hub actions for pausing jobs, managing iFlows and performing restarts safely
  3. Context and safeguards: Supplying metadata so Joule executes only on the right systems, with test harnesses for edge cases
  4. Governed deployment: Leveraging accelerated compliance checks provided by RunMyJobs‚Äô SAP Endorsed App Premium certification to reliably execute controlled deployment across SAP environments

How RunMyJobs and Joule Studio connect

The integration between RunMyJobs and Joule Studio allows your teams to innovate safely across SAP environments and in various scenarios. The process looks like this:

  1. Publish operations in RunMyJobs, such as starting or pausing jobs.
  2. Publish actions to the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, making them available as reusable building blocks. 
  3. Secure access through SAP BTP using API keys and role-based permissions. You then govern access to these operations within the SAP BTP Cockpit. 
  4. Combine these actions in Joule Studio to build skills that connect automation with natural language requests.

This framework lets IT and business teams interact with automation directly in their workflow tools, so it‚Äôs governed, auditable and ready for expansion.

The future of automation is a conversation

We are only at the starting line of what‚Äôs possible. The combination of RunMyJobs and SAP Joule is laying the foundation for agentic automation across finance, supply chain, HR, IT and beyond. As SAP continues to advance its Business AI capabilities, Redwood will keep embedding orchestration where it matters most: within the business conversation.

entry.title: Top 9 takeaways #SAPConnect 2025
entry.content:
1. The "Global Maxima" Strategy: Why the "App + Data + AI" Flywheel is the Core Bet

What was announced: SAP's core strategic argument stays consistent - that "a seamless app, data, and AI flywheel creates the highest value". This model, where all three components are part of a single, integrated suite, was positioned as the only way to win in the new age of AI.

The "So What": This was a direct declaration that the integrated suite is superior to a "best-of-breed" approach. Muhammad argued that AI with the "broadest context" (drawn from a full suite) will always provide the "deepest value". He explicitly stated that standalone players focusing on just one or two domains "will then, by definition, struggle to create enterprise-wide value with AI". For SAP, this "out-of-the-box harmonized data model" is no longer just a nice-to-have; it's the essential foundation for achieving "global maxima" and avoiding the integration tax and "opportunity cost" of a fragmented landscape.

1. SAP's "App + Data + AI" Flywheel Concept

 

2. Joule, Agents, and AI Assistants: The New Operating Model

What was announced: SAP is operationalizing its AI strategy through a new hierarchy:

  • Joule: The single conversational "Gen UI" that acts as the engagement layer.
  • Agents: The specialized "tools" that perform specific tasks.
  • AI Assistants: Role-specific partners, such as a "Receivable Assistant," "Controlling Assistant," or "Sourcing Assistant", which have these agents at their disposal.

The "So What": This is the "how" behind the "what." Stefan's end-to-end demo showed Joule as the single interface to drive insights and actions across the entire business suite, from procurement-to-pay to order-to-cash. Priyanka's demo took this a step further, showing an "operations assistant" for a plant manager, which then orchestrated multiple agents (like the "asset health agent," "maintenance planner agent," and "procurement assistant") to resolve a complex machine breakdown. This signals a fundamental redesign of the user experience, moving from clicking through apps to orchestrating complex, cross-functional outcomes.

2. Joule, Agents, and AI Assistants_The New Operating Model

 3. The 5 Patterns of AI: A New Framework for Business Applications

What was announced: The keynote introduced a five-pattern framework to explain how AI will "fundamentally reinvent business applications".

The "So What": This conceptual framework is a crucial guide for business leaders planning their AI roadmaps. It shows a multi-pronged innovation strategy, acknowledging that different processes will be transformed in different ways. The five patterns are:

  1. Seamlessly embedded AI and agentic experiences.
  2. Agent-driven autonomous execution capabilities.
  3. Truly AI-native applications built from the ground up.
  4. App-less experiences driven by a conversational layer.
  5. No-apps experiences where the app is generated in real-time.

3. The 5 Patterns of AI_A New Framework for Business Applications

 

4. From Insight-to-Action... to Autonomous Execution

What was announced: SAP is aggressively pushing beyond simple AI recommendations toward "agent-driven autonomous execution".

The "So What": This is the end-game. The keynote stressed that this evolution will happen as "your colleague has built enough trust on the assistant's performance". Priyanka's demo of an "autonomous maintenance and repair operation" was the flagship example. The vision is for the system to autonomously handle an entire complex event - from detecting a machine failure to identifying orders at risk, ordering the spare part from a supplier, and dispatching the best technician,... with the human partner simply monitoring and approving, not executing the workflow.

4. From Insight to Action to Autonomous Execution

5. "Deep Research": Joule's New High-Value Skill

What was announced: A powerful new capability in Joule called "deep research" was introduced and demoed.

The "So What": This is where SAP expects to unlock "100x type use cases for value". Instead of just answering simple, transactional queries, "deep research" allows Joule to synthesize "vast amounts of internal and external data" to answer complex, strategic questions. The example of compressing a 6-8 week account planning process into "just a few hours" - by synthesizing history, surfacing drivers, comparing playbooks, and drafting a plan - is a tangible game-changer for any go-to-market organization.

5. Deep Research in Joule

 

6. Truly AI-Native Applications Arrive (Supply Chain & Ariba)

What was announced: SAP unveiled its first "truly AI-native applications", making good on the promise of its 5-pattern framework.

The "So What": This proves the framework isn't just theory. The new Supply Chain Orchestration solution was the prime example, described as a "GPS for your supply chain" that uses a "network knowledge graph" to analyze real-time signals, assess risk, and suggest alternatives. The major SAP Ariba source-to-pay suite update was also positioned as "AI-native", enabling an "agentic and autonomous" approach to procurement. For existing customers, the most important line was the promise that this Ariba update will be "a non-disruptive update... that will not require a re-implementation"

6. Supply Chain Orchestration

 

7. "Skills are the New Supply Chain"

What was announced: The "Future of Work" segment, featuring Chief People Officer of SAP, Gina Vargiu-Breuer and futurist Ian Beecraft, reframed the entire human-AI partnership around the concept of "skills".

The "So What": This segment's most memorable line was Gina's: "skills are the new supply chain". With the shelf-life of technical skills plummeting to 18-36 months, the focus must shift from static "jobs" to a dynamic "skills-first" approach. AI is positioned as the enabler, allowing employees to "stretch into adjacent territories and skills" - for example, a financial planner using AI to perform predictive analytics without needing a data science degree. This makes a strong case for SAP SuccessFactors as the critical platform for managing this new, fast-moving "supply chain" of talent.

8. Business Data Cloud Gets Smarter with "Intelligent Applications"

What was announced: SAP is expanding its Business Data Cloud offering with a new suite of "intelligent applications".

The "So What": This is the "Data" layer of the flywheel in action. The new apps: Finance Intelligence, Supply Chain Intelligence, Revenue Intelligence, and Consumer Products Intelligence ... are designed to sit on top of the harmonized data layer and provide the "broadest context" the AI flywheel needs. This move elevates the Business Data Cloud from a purely technical "data fabric" into a tangible value-delivery platform, providing the out-of-the-box insights that fuel the AI assistants.

8. Business Data Cloud Gets Smarter with Intelligent Applications

 

9. SAP Engagement Cloud: Orchestrating Journeys Beyond Marketing

What was announced: The launch of the new SAP Engagement Cloud, a platform designed to "harmonize business data into actionable segments, triggers and journeys" for hyper-personalization.

The "So What": The key insight is that "engagement" is an enterprise-wide challenge, not just a marketing one. The demos pointedly showed this new cloud working for HR (orchestrating an alumni event) and Procurement (managing a supplier compliance journey). By creating a single, unified engine for all enterprise touchpoints - across HCM, procurement, and service - SAP is delivering on the "global maxima" theme, ensuring that every interaction, whether with a customer, supplier, or employee, is seamless and intelligent.

Limitations (as of Q3 2025 Release)

    • Joule does not currently support multi-tenant consolidation. Run Joule Booster in every child realm to overcome this limitation.

entry.title: Expiring Price Handling Powered by Joule
entry.content:
The Joule capability "Expiring Price Handling" has been released in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502.3. This blog introduces this feature in detail, so that you can interact with Joule smoothly and manage expiring prices efficiently. 

 

Overview

You can ask Joule to fetch prices (stored as condition records for pricing in sales in the system) that will expire soon. For expiring prices, Joule can help renew them by extending their validity periods and adjusting the condition amounts or ratios according to your requirements. After you confirm to extend the expiring prices, a price renewal background job will be created. You can also check the progress and result of the price renewal job via Joule.

Figure 1

Please check out the following help document and demo for a glimpse.

    • Help Document: Renew Expiring Prices
    • Demo: Renew Product Prices with Joule

 

Feature in Details

 

Definition of "Expiring Price"

Before using this feature, it's important to understand what qualifies as an "Expiring Price". Joule retrieves prices that expire between the current date and the given date (including both dates) without a successor record. Only records without a successor are considered "Expiring".

  • Case 1 and 2: Prices without a successor --> considered "expiring". 
  • Case 3: Even if its Valid-To date falls between the current date and the given date, it has a successor with a continuous validity period starting right after its Valid-To date --> not considered "expiring".
  • Case 4: Already expired prices --> not considered "expiring".

Figure 2

Note that, this feature only retrieves/renews the prices approaching expiration (meaning still valid for the time being), but cannot fetch/renew the prices which are already expired (Case 4 above).

 

How Are Expiring Prices Renewed?

Instead of updating the original Valid-To date of the expiring price, Joule creates a new continuous validity period for the expiring price (with Valid-From date set to the date one day after the Valid-To date of the expiring price). Optionally, the new validity period could have a new condition amount/ratio. The purpose of this is to keep the existing "Expiring Price" unchanged, but create its successor only.

Do take note that, the new validity being created could possibly overlap with the existing validity that lies in future, such as the Case 2 above. Assume that the gap between the expiring price and its future validity is 9 months long. If we extend the validity period of the expiring price by 1 year, the new validity and existing future validity will overlap for 3 months. In this case, the new validity will overwrite the existing validity during the overlapped period.

 

Always Start from "Show Expiring Prices"

You can activate the "Expiring Price Handling" feature by talking to Joule with phrases like below:

  • "Show me prices for sales organization 1710 that expire before December 31, 2025."
  • "List the prices with condition type PPR0 that are expiring before Dec 31, 2025."
  • "Are there any prices for condition type PPR0 and sales organization 1010 expiring before December 31, 2025?"

Even if you ask Joule to extend the expiring price directly, you will be redirected to show expiring prices, because the extension/renewal could only be performed on the expiring prices already listed in Joule.

Figure 3

Expiration date is a mandatory for querying expiring prices. If the date is not given, Joule will prompt you to provide one, so that it can proceed to search for the expiring prices.

Figure 4

For best results, include at least one of the following filters in your query. Currently, these are the only fields supported as the filter.

  • Condition type
  • Sales organization
  • Distribution channel
  • Product
  • Customer
  • Customer project ID
 
Expiration Urgency Level

The expiring prices will be listed and sorted by urgency:

  • Red:  ‚â§30 days left before expiration
  • Orange:  31~60 days left before expiration
  • Green:  >60 days left before expiration

Figure 5

 

Dynamic Grouping

At the time this blog is being written, Joule can display up to 30 prices per message. If more than 30 expiring prices are found, they will be grouped dynamically,  for example:

  • By condition type + sales org. + urgency level.
  • By condition type + urgency level.
  • By urgency level only.

This ensures the total number of groups is kept ‚â§30.

Figure 6

 

Check Price Renewal Job Log

After clicking "Confirm" to extend prices, a mass creation job will be created in the background to create the new validity periods. You can check progress and result of the renewal job by clicking the "Check Progress" button. The job result is summarized in a card format. You can click "Open in App" to navigate to the "Manage Prices - Sales" app to check the details of the job.

Figure 7

Alternatively, you can also go to "Manage Prices - Sales" app --> click "Monitor Imports and Jobs" at the upper-right corner. --> switch to "Scheduled Jobs" tab. All the previously created jobs are listed, including the mass creation job created from "Manage Prices - Sales" app. Note that the price renewal jobs created via Joule are always named "Price Renewal xxxxxxxxxxxxxx".

Figure 8

 

Limitations

Instability of Resolving Expiration Date

If you ask Joule to show the prices expiring in N months/days, Joule may occasionally resolve the expiration date incorrectly. This can lead to an inaccurate or empty results. This is because the current LLMs do not inherently have awareness of real-time information.

Thus, we recommend providing specific dates to Joule, such as "Show me prices that are going to expire before 31 Dec, 2025" or "List prices due to expire on 31/03/2026".

 

Short Request Timeout

There's a short request timeout (only 15 seconds) imposed by Joule on any API call to backend. If you don't provide any filter criteria, you may encounter a timeout.

Figure 9

Therefore, always include at least one of the supported filters while asking Joule to show the expiring prices.

entry.title: KI-Agenten bei SAP: √úberblick, Beispiele, Umsetzung und Adoption mit Jochen Schneider
entry.content:
Stell Dir vor, du gibst deinem zehnj√§hrigen Kind morgens die Anweisung: "In zehn Minuten fahren wir zur Schule." Was passiert? Im Idealfall zieht es sich selbstst√§ndig an ‚Äì Hose, Schuhe, Jacke ‚Äì und steht bereit. Genau so funktionieren KI-Agenten. Diese Metapher nutzt Jochen Schneider, verantwortlich f√ºr AI Capabilities auf der SAP Business Technology Platform, um zu erkl√§ren, was Agentic AI von herk√∂mmlichen Gen-AI-L√∂sungen unterscheidet. Im aktuellen EducationNewscast gibt er einen umfassenden Einblick in die Welt der KI-Agenten bei SAP ‚Äì von den Grundlagen √ºber praktische Beispiele bis hin zu konkreten Tipps f√ºr den Einstieg.

Hier eine Zusammenfassung des fast einst√ºndigen Interviews und Gespr√§ch - reinh√∂ren k√∂nnt ihr hier auf SAP-Podcasts - Apple - oder Spotify. Da das Thema so wichtig und spannend ist, denke ich, dass eine Zusammenfassung des Talks auch hier in der Gruppe von Interesse ist.

Was KI-Agenten wirklich ausmacht

Der Unterschied zwischen einem klassischen Chatbot oder Assistenten und einem KI-Agenten ist fundamental. W√§hrend du bei ChatGPT einen Prompt eingibst und eine Antwort erh√§ltst, arbeiten Agenten deutlich komplexer und autonomer. Jochen erkl√§rt das Prinzip anhand seiner Kinder: Du gibst nicht jeden einzelnen Schritt vor ("Zieh die Hose an, dann die Schuhe"), sondern beschreibst das gew√ºnschte Ergebnis. Der Agent findet dann selbst heraus, welche Schritte n√∂tig sind, um dieses Ziel zu erreichen.

Damit ein Agent funktioniert, braucht er drei zentrale Komponenten: Tools (die "H√§nde", um Aktionen auszuf√ºhren), Reasoning-F√§higkeiten (den "Kopf", um Entscheidungen zu treffen) und Memory (das "Ged√§chtnis", um Kontext zu behalten und aus Erfahrungen zu lernen). Diese Kombination erm√∂glicht es Agenten, komplexe Aufgaben eigenst√§ndig zu bew√§ltigen, ohne dass du jeden Zwischenschritt vorgeben musst.

Ein wichtiger Punkt, den Jochen betont: Nicht alles sollte oder muss zum Agenten werden.
